div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, July 3, 1887
div1.p:
The one absorbing topic of interest
just now in N. O. is the weather - 4 1/2 inches of rain fell
in 1 1/2 hours Wednesday & simply flooded things
As 9 3/4 inches fell in one storm in April/83, when
I was here, it isn't so much a matter of surprise
However there was no ground visible from La fay-
ette square to La,' Avenue - (above the car stables)
about 3 miles & in the back of the town - every
thing was over flowed. Water from 1 to 3 feet deep
up Camp & Magazine streets & running like
a mill race, - it has been raining a good deal
ever since - also Monday & Tuesday. It has ruin-
ed all ripening figs & melons (water & cantelopes) - of which we had
no end- If it stops we will have 1/4 of a crop
left. We are grieved about the figs, - with milk
they are better than peaches & require no sugar, raw
about as good as the average soft peach-very nourishing & L.' Jr.
& Sr. very fond of them & they are very wholesome.

Saturday week at 3.50 P. M. I rec'd a telegram “to send
all available tents ”to Tampa Fla” & I started to pack
them up at 4. P. M & had 690 tents, & the full
complement of poles pins &c ready for shipment
by Sunday night. Could not, ship until Monday
because the Express Co would not receive them Sunday,
I shipped them in the rain Monday & Tuesday morning
(10, 3 horse float loads) & don't think I ever had a
more annoying job. Tell Aunt May I kept the childrens tent
as I had only 420 on my Property Roll I could do so, also it has a hole in it
We also had fire June 30 & there has been no single
hot night yet. Also the rains will make the city healthier.

My new steward will I think be satisfactory- I will
probably have a little (not much) more work & about 3/4 less
annoyance than with Mr. Richardson. He is unmarried
but I think intends “to change all that” in the fall
“Maguire” - a Baltimorean. Both L. & I keep well also the
children - one doesn't feel as he does in Amherst, but well enough.
Tell May that our bathire has gained from 20 to 100 feet (in different places) which
will require a lengthening of our pipes to a corresponding
amount.
We have taken a few in Trinity regularly now.

I had a letter from Chas. yesterday. We can tell nothing about how he
is getting on. I think better - Also one from Jno. Dox, he will hardly
recover I fear: & I hardly know how to answer him. I am offered
a share in a practice in Cairo (1/2 of what is said to a $5000 to $6000, prac-
tice) & have written for details. I do not think that I will accept, being
timid about ventures now. I hope in a little while 18 mos to get $2500, & rent &c
Wish I had had such a chance 4 years ago, give my love to all
& give me all the news from Va.

A Dr. Montiero from Manchester Va: who seemed to have met Hill & indeed
everybody else I every knew in Va: He is a queer old fellow. Although I liked him
Is at Ship Island, staid 4 1/2 days with us.
div1.closer: Your affec'ate son H. R. Carter.
